description: A five-slide presentation with key information about the Bald Eagle.
title: All About the Bald Eagle

slides.title: Introduction to the Bald Eagle
slides.content: The Bald Eagle (Haliaeetus leucocephalus) is a majestic bird of prey and North America's national symbol. Known for its impressive size and striking appearance, it was once endangered but has made a remarkable recovery through conservation efforts.

slides.title: Physical Characteristics
content: Adults have white heads and tails with dark brown bodies, yellow beaks, and feet, growing up to 3 feet long with a wingspan of 6-7 feet.
Young eagles are mostly brown and don't develop the distinctive white head until they are 4-5 years old.

slides.title: Hunting and Feeding
content: Bald Eagles are opportunistic hunters, primarily feeding on fish but also eating birds, mammals, and carrion.
They have excellent eyesight (8 times better than humans) and can spot prey from up to 2 miles away.

slides.title: Flight and Behavior
content: Bald Eagles are powerful fliers, reaching speeds up to 40 mph and soaring to altitudes of 10,000 feet.
They perform spectacular aerial courtship displays, including cartwheeling and locking talons while falling through the sky.

slides.title: Conservation Success Story
content: Once reduced to about 400 breeding pairs due to habitat loss and DDT poisoning, Bald Eagles now number over 70,000 in North America.
They are the national bird of the United States and serve as an important symbol of environmental conservation and recovery.
